nl.strohalm.cyclos.services.stats
Class HistogramDTOFactory

java.lang.Object
  nl.strohalm.cyclos.services.stats.HistogramDTOFactory

public class HistogramDTOFactory
extends java.lang.Object

This class takes a simple list with data, retrieved straight from a database query, and uses it to create a StatisticalResultDTO value object for the creation of a Histogram. The list of data is divided into histogram categories of reasonable size for the statistics graphs.

Beware: the class cannot handle negative x-axis values. It starts counting at 0, so if the x-axis factor has negative values, then the first category on the x-axis will be VERY big, because it also contains all x-values < 0. In this case, no exception is raised, but the figure looks rather silly, with one big first category, and the rest of the x-axis categories very tiny.

Beware 2:
Note that lists of Integers and Lists of Doubles are treated differently, especially where it concerns the division over x-axis categories. You should NOT enter a List of numbers which represent integer values as a List of Doubles. If you do so, the x-axis categories will use irrelevant broken numbers and your histograph may contain a lot of silly gaps..

Author:
Rinke

HistogramDTOFactory

public HistogramDTOFactory(java.util.List<java.lang.Number> input,
                           LocalSettings settings)
constructor, storing the input in its appropriate field, and storing the settings.

Parameters:
input - - the List<Number> with the data to put in the histogram. Note that lists of Integers and Lists of Doubles are treated differently, especially where it concerns the division over x-axis categories. You should NOT enter a List of numbers which represent integer values as a List of Doubles. If you do so, the x-axis categories will use irrelevant broken numbers and your histograph may contain a lot of silly gaps..
settings - - a LocalSettings, in order to format the numbers. Null value is allowed.
